fields.title:
Oviri (Die Eingeborene)
[Hier wird Rassismus perpetuiert. Siehe Anmerkung.]
fields.title_english:
Oviri (The Native)
[Racism is perpetuated here. See comments.]
fields.comments:
The term “native” derives from the Latin word natus, and has been used to describe people born to a particular place. 
While it was commonly used historically, the term has been criticized for not only reinforcing colonial hierarchies—natives were regarded as inferior to the civilized colonizer—but also (contradictorily) for implying an exclusionary racial and ethnic right to a place by a specific group. 
The term is currently used by some, for example, Native Americans, in their political claims for sovereignty. Within Europe this concept is increasingly used in xenophobic politics. 
Source: Words Matter – An Unfinished Guide to Word Choices in the Cultural Sector. Online: https://www.materialculture.nl/en/creditss/words-matter
fields.credits: Antoinette Le Normand-Romain (u.a.), Skulptur- Die Moderne 19. und 20. Jahrhundert, Köln 1996, S.115

fields.title:
Der Sklavenmarkt (Le Marché d'esclaves)
[Hier wird neben Sexismus auch Rassismus perpetuiert. Siehe Anmerkung.]
fields.title_english:
The Slave Market (Le Marché d'esclaves)
[Beside sexism also racism is perpetuated here. See comments.]
fields.comments:
Oriental
The term “Oriental” derives from the Latin word “Oriënt”, meaning east. Historically, the term came to be used in Europe to describe people or things from Asia. 
“Oriental” gained widespread critique after the 1978 credits of Edward Said’s seminal work Orientalism, which critiqued Euro-American patronizing representations of the (Middle) East. 
While the term is contested for being geographically Eurocentric, and especially for its romanticizing and stereotypical image of Asian people as mysterious, “exotic” and foreign, it is still widely used. 

Slave
The term “slave” is used to describe a person who is the legal property of another and is forced to obey them by law and/or by force.
The term itself refers to different forms of un-freedom, with different meanings and consequences over time and place. In the 6th century, for example, “sklabos” (Greek) meant an un-free person of Slavic descent, while in medieval Latin “sclavus” more generally meant “a person who is owned by another.”
Today, the term is more generally used to describe people from Africa who were bought/captured and enslaved by Europeans and forced to work on plantations, often under inhumane conditions, within European colonial projects.
Increasingly “slave” has become contested by activists, scholars and the public alike, as it is argued that using the term is to normalize the category “slave” as an inherent identity of a person, thus ignoring that this identity was created not by choice but through violent force. The term also denies the humanity of the person, reducing them to being no more than the property of another.
Recently the term has been used to describe the victims of contemporary human trafficking or forced labor.
Words Matter – An Unfinished Guide to Word Choices in the Cultural Sector. Online: https://www.materialculture.nl/en/creditss/words-matter (lemma slightly modified) // Der Darstellungsinhalt stellt einen Bezug zum Haremsmotiv (eingesperrte Sex-Sklavinnen in Aktdarstellungen in einer kontrollierten Umgebung) dar (Förschler 2010: 228-231), greift jedoch auch den Sklavenhandel auf, durch die Situierung in den Osten, kann jedoch die europäische Verwicklung bewusst vernachlässigt werden (Schmidt-Linsenhoff 2004: 35-52). Die Verlegung nach Kairo und die ärmliche Inszenierung  begleitet das koloniale Interesse der Westmächte an Ägypten (Förschler 2004: 230). (Silke Förschler, Bilder des Harems (2010), Viktoria Schmidt-Linsenhoff, Weiße Blicke. Geschlechtermythen des Kolonialismus (2004))

The term “Oriental” derives from the Latin word “Oriënt”, meaning east. Historically, the term came to be used in Europe to describe people or things from Asia. 
“Oriental” gained widespread critique after the 1978 credits of Edward Said’s seminal work Orientalism, which critiqued Euro-American patronizing representations of the (Middle) East. 
While the term is contested for being geographically Eurocentric, and especially for its romanticizing and stereotypical image of Asian people as mysterious, “exotic” and foreign, it is still widely used.

fields.title:
"Navio negreiro": Sklaven im Unterdeck eines Sklavenschiffs
[Zur Einordnung des Begriffs “Sklave” siehe Anmerkung.]
fields.title_english:
"Navio negreiro": Slaves kept in the cellar of a slave boat
[For the classification of the term "slave" see comments.]
fields.comments:
The term “slave” is used to describe a person who is the legal property of another and is forced to obey them by law and/or by force.
The term itself refers to different forms of un-freedom, with different meanings and consequences over time and place. In the 6th century, for example, “sklabos” (Greek) meant an un-free person of Slavic descent, while in medieval Latin “sclavus” more generally meant “a person who is owned by another.”
Today, the term is more generally used to describe people from Africa who were bought/captured and enslaved by Europeans and forced to work on plantations, often under inhumane conditions, within European colonial projects.
Increasingly “slave” has become contested by activists, scholars and the public alike, as it is argued that using the term is to normalize the category “slave” as an inherent identity of a person, thus ignoring that this identity was created not by choice but through violent force. The term also denies the humanity of the person, reducing them to being no more than the property of another.
Recently the term has been used to describe the victims of contemporary human trafficking or forced labor.
Words Matter – An Unfinished Guide to Word Choices in the Cultural Sector. Online: https://www.materialculture.nl/en/creditss/words-matter 

Originaltitel Navio negreiro nach einem Gedicht von Castro Alvez
